1918. Keys, (Mrs. Joseph)
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About half a dozen.

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors—some of us being very friendly and others not so friendly?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days?

Church on Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? If yes, who went away with you and what did you do there?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

If you had a meal in the early days, did you have a neighbor's home without hard work? (That is, was the term to make potluck used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

To eat with it, nothing very elaborate, but always welcome.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay at home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, there were many "bees" in early years, from raising cattle to building fences.

Tell me about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

These were parties and dances in the homes, but what drives to me were unknown.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Whenever the home was large enough to accommodate the people and a shelter for the horses, three people often took their turns as well as the owner of the house with smaller buildings.
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About half a dozen.

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Sometimes, but not regularly.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually on Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Sometimes, but not regularly.

What time of the day did you go? In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually in the afternoon.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually, but not always.

Was there a meal served by the hostess? Usually, but not always.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Always tea and something to eat with it, nothing very elaborate, but always welcome.

5. Did the whole family go? Or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities? Yes, there were many.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were parties and dances in the homes, but whirl-dances to me were uncommon.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

In later years, yes.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from house to house, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Whenever the house was large enough to accommodate the people, then both their rooms as well as the living room with smaller buildings.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school district name, type, location, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

The school was always the main centre for social activities (my spelling and writing are going modern)

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built? What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? If so, why?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Authors

Has there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community purposes, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school children's clubs, games, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

The school was always the main centre for social activities (many spelling and writing are very modern)

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Within the school.

9. When was your first community hall built? No hall means no story

What material was it made of? Timber

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, etc.? If so, why?)

The Fairville people still use the local school house for district gatherings and go to either hall for something different.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Always in the school district.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Outlaw

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Yes, everything went smoothly in the town.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attitudes at formality or "awake" do you remember in small towns such as Elmo and Alta when calling, calling cards, visiting, treated aggressively.

13. Was the obivouse known in your community? You

Describe what you remember about obivouse, telling how common they were.

Incidents connected with them, etc.

For some years they seemed to go out by fashion, but are not to be discarded as undesirable.

Describe any other details of clothing, parties, etc., that you remember.

Telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates when you can when same changed.

In visiting or social life became noticeable.

Some time between 1894 and 1896.

Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community?

Yes.

Organized sometime about 1911.

How many women belonged? You

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Ball was always the main game—hand softball and foot-ball.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Ball and skipping rope.

26. Who organized it? The citizens of the district.

32. Usually started in morning and lasted all day.
31. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The only thing on the picnic grounds was a sod building and during the afternoon a little hall where games were played by a hearty crowd of young people. The sods didn't last very well.

32. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family, food and drink, etc., tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, etc.

The picnics in the early years were usually held at a local park or on the grounds of a nearby school. Everyone looked forward to these events as they provided an opportunity to enjoy the outdoors and socialize with friends and family.

33. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

The co-op picnic is now disappearing. At a certain point in time, the idea of having a picnic became less popular, and people began to prefer other forms of entertainment.

34. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in them.

One popular sport was baseball, played largely by boys. The Englishmen in the district, particularly the men, played baseball regularly.

35. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

That year?

How long did it continue?

36. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1911, giving date of organization if possible and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

37. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.), the C.P.R. came at that time.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? April 1896
35. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The only thing I can remember about this picnic was the large community picnic which you know of in the early days such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family, food and drinks, etc., tell about them.

The proceeds from these picnics were usually used to attend every one took lunch and all sat together on the grass or at tables to eat. Lemonade and water were used as the main drink, pop was called soft drinks.

36. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

The go-go spirit was lacking in the early years, but now very evident that there was a big change in attitude.

Once popular sport was cricket played largely by the Englishmen in the district, mainly by men.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

That year?

How long did it continue?

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? A violin.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors bring?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. An organ in 1918.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Singing was largely used as a means of entertainment in the early years in the West.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

There was group singing at parties and musical concerts.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

In the community?

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? If so, when was it started? How long did it continue? Who started it? John Brown.

How many were in it? About 15 who was bandmaster? John Brown.

What instruments were included? All the different instruments that went to make up a real good band.

Tell what you remember of its activities; how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for. The members did not have uniforms. Practice was mostly held in Opeby Lake school that being most central. Most of the older members were Moan family and had played in the band before coming west when these older ones had passed on, none were left who cared about carrying on the music.
